passage_text: close•up. 1. a photograph taken at close range or with a long focal-length lens. 2. a movie or television shot in which some part of the subject, as the head of an actor, fills the entire frame. 3. an intimate view or presentation of anything.

Macro photography; Close-up photography; photomacrography; macrography. A form of photography in which the subject of the photograph is usually very small or is a very small detail of a larger object. The resultant Photograph is larger than life size. Macro photographs are taken from extreme close-up range. This allows the image on the sensor plane to be equal to life size or greater.
close-up. n. 1. (Photography) a photograph or film or television shot taken at close range. 2. a detailed or intimate view or examination: a close-up of modern society.

Close-up. A picture taken with the subject close to the camera. The classic close-up is about getting detail. That usually means getting right into the subject. The feeling of ‘closeness’ usually means the shot is taken from less than meter away.
